¿	The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Plant stores a 24 percent concentration aqueous ammonia in a 40,000 gallon above-ground storage tank (AST) which is located at the base of the PH/PC kiln system.  This AST is equipped with secondary containment.  Also, the Plant will receive 6,000 gallon tanker trucks alternatively delivering approximately 19.5 percent and approximately 30 percent aqueous ammonia, since the manufacturer does not produce 24 percent aqueous ammonia.  As a result, the Plant is required to develop and submit to the U.S. EPA, per 40 CFR 68, a RMP since aqueous ammonia at a 20 percent or greater concentration that is stored in the 40,000 gallon AST exceeds the threshold storage limit of 20,000 gallons as stipulated in Table 1 of 40 CFR 68.130.

¿	Five-Year Accident History

The Plant has had no accidents, including spills, associated with the operation of the 40,000 gallon aqueous ammonia AST in the last five years.  The tank was commissioned in March 2011.

¿	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It should be noted that Program Level 1 requirements do not include providing a prevention program.  Only Program Level 2 and 3 require a prevention program per 40 CFR 68.170 and 175, respectively.  An overview of the Plant's existing prevention program is described below to meet 40 CFR 68.155 requirements for addressing prevention requirements.

The Plant maintains the following prevention and emergency response plans:

1.	Contingency Plan (for hazardous waste generated episodically)
2.	Emergency Response and Disaster Control Plan
3.	Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasures (SPCC) Plan

¿	General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps Emergency Response Program

An emergency response program was developed for the purpose of protecting the Plant employee's health and to protect the environment.  The Plant emergency response program includes the following elements: 

¿	The Plant has developed and implemented an Emergency Response Procedure (Procedure) which meets the emergency response program requirements specified in §68.90 and §68.95.  The Procedure is presented in Appendix B.  The purpose of this Procedure is to protect the public health and the environment and specifically addresses the following elements: 

-	Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases; 

-	Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures per MSHA guidelines;  

-	Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of a regulated substance; 

-	Training for all employees in relevant procedures; and 

-	Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes at the Plant and that it ensures that employees are informed of changes. 

As stipulated in 40 CFR 68.95(b), the Procedure complies with other Federal contingency plan regulations or is consistent with the approach in the National Response Team's Integrated Contingency Plan Guidance.   

For compliance with 40 CFR 68.95(c), the applicable elements of the Procedure are coordinated with the local community. Executive Summary

This revised Risk Management Plan (RMP) was developed for Lehigh Cement Company LLC (Lehigh) per Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA) solely for the purpose of storing aqueous ammonia (i.e., ammonium hydroxide) above the threshold reporting quantity of 19.5 percent.  The RMP was developed following U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) guidance documents and 40 CFR Part 68 (Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions).   This revised RMP is being submitted to reflect Program Level 1 requirements as a result of a recent U.S. EPA review of the original RMP submitted by Lehigh to the U.S. EPA in 2017.

The revised RMP describes and details the evaluation in determining Lehigh's process per §68.3, Program Level assignment (§68.1) and various applicable site level prevention programs (§68 Subpart C).  The Plant Registration Form is presented in Section 2.0.  Section 3.0 provides the results of the hazards assessment, and Section 4.0 presented the Plant's emergency response program.   

The result of the Plant's revised risk management evaluation is summarized below:

¿	Storage of 24 percent aqueous ammonia in a 40,000 gallon AST triggers RMP,
¿	Process is storage of aqueous ammonia solution (CAS Nos. : 1336-21-6 and  7664-41-7), and
¿	RMPComp modeling results of a worst-case release scenario (§68.25) result in a Program Level 1 designation.
     
Per §68.155, the Executive Summary of the RMP is required to include a brief description of the following: 

¿	The stationary source and regulated substances handled; 
¿	The five-year accident history;
¿	The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies; 
¿	The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps; 
¿	The emergency response program; and
¿	Planned changes to improve safety.
